lines.text: Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and LADY GREY

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain, His lands then seized on by the conqueror: Her suit is now to repossess those lands; Which we in justice cannot well deny, Because in quarrel of the house of York The worthy gentleman did lose his life.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Your highness shall do well to grant her suit; It were dishonour to deny it her.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: It were no less; but yet I'll make a pause.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Yea, is it so? I see the lady hath a thing to grant, Before the king will grant her humble suit.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He knows the game: how true he keeps the wind!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Silence!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Widow, we will consider of your suit; And come some other time to know our mind.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Right gracious lord, I cannot brook delay: May it please your highness to resolve me now; And what your pleasure is, shall satisfy me.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, widow? then I'll warrant you all your lands, An if what pleases him shall pleasure you. Fight closer, or, good faith, you'll catch a blow.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I fear her not, unless she chance to fall.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE] God forbid that! for he'll take vantages.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: How many children hast thou, widow? tell me.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  I think he means to beg a child of her.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Nay, whip me then: he'll rather give her two.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Three, my most gracious lord.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  You shall have four, if you'll be ruled by him.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: 'Twere pity they should lose their father's lands.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Be pitiful, dread lord, and grant it then.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Lords, give us leave: I'll try this widow's wit.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  Ay, good leave have you; for you will have leave, Till youth take leave and leave you to the crutch.
GLOUCESTER and CLARENCE retire

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: And would you not do much to do them good?

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: To do them good, I would sustain some harm.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Then get your husband's lands, to do them good.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Therefore I came unto your majesty.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: I'll tell you how these lands are to be got.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: So shall you bind me to your highness' service.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: What service wilt thou do me, if I give them?

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: What you command, that rests in me to do.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: No, gracious lord, except I cannot do it.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Ay, but thou canst do what I mean to ask.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Why, then I will do what your grace commands.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  He plies her hard; and much rain wears the marble.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  As red as fire! nay, then her wax must melt.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: That's soon perform'd, because I am a subject.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why, then, thy husband's lands I freely give thee.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: I take my leave with many thousand thanks.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The match is made; she seals it with a curtsy.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: But stay thee, 'tis the fruits of love I mean.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: The fruits of love I mean, my loving liege.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Ay, but, I fear me, in another sense. What love, think'st thou, I sue so much to get?

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: My love till death, my humble thanks, my prayers; That love which virtue begs and virtue grants.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: No, by my troth, I did not mean such love.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: My mind will never grant what I perceive Your highness aims at, if I aim aright.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Why, then mine honesty shall be my dower; For by that loss I will not purchase them.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Therein thou wrong'st thy children mightily.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Herein your highness wrongs both them and me. But, mighty lord, this merry inclination Accords not with the sadness of my suit: Please you dismiss me either with 'ay' or 'no.'

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request; No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The widow likes him not, she knits her brows.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  He is the bluntest wooer in Christendom.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: [Aside]  Her looks do argue her replete with modesty; Her words do show her wit incomparable; All her perfections challenge sovereignty: One way or other, she is for a king; And she shall be my love, or else my queen.-- Say that King Edward take thee for his queen?

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: 'Tis better said than done, my gracious lord: I am a subject fit to jest withal, But far unfit to be a sovereign.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Sweet widow, by my state I swear to thee I speak no more than what my soul intends; And that is, to enjoy thee for my love.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: And that is more than I will yield unto: I know I am too mean to be your queen, And yet too good to be your concubine.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: You cavil, widow: I did mean, my queen.

lines.speaker: lady grey
lines.text: 'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: No more than when my daughters call thee mother. Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor, Have other some: why, 'tis a happy thing To be the father unto many sons. Answer no more, for thou shalt be my queen.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: [Aside to CLARENCE]  The ghostly father now hath done his shrift.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: [Aside to GLOUCESTER]  When he was made a shriver, 'twas for shift.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Brothers, you muse what chat we two have had.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: The widow likes it not, for she looks very sad.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: You'll think it strange if I should marry her.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: To whom, my lord?

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why, Clarence, to myself.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: By so much is the wonder in extremes.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.
Enter a Nobleman

lines.speaker: nobleman
lines.text: My gracious lord, Henry your foe is taken, And brought your prisoner to your palace gate.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: See that he be convey'd unto the Tower: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him, To question of his apprehension. Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Ay, Edward will use women honourably. Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all, That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring, To cross me from the golden time I look for! And yet, between my soul's desire and me-- The lustful Edward's title buried-- Is Clarence, Henry, and his son young Edward, And all the unlook'd for issue of their bodies, To take their rooms, ere I can place myself: A cold premeditation for my purpose! Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty; Like one that stands upon a promontory, And spies a far-off shore where he would tread, Wishing his foot were equal with his eye, And chides the sea that sunders him from thence, Saying, he'll lade it dry to have his way: So do I wish the crown, being so far off; And so I chide the means that keeps me from it; And so I say, I'll cut the causes off, Flattering me with impossibilities. My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much, Unless my hand and strength could equal them. Well, say there is no kingdom then for Richard; What other pleasure can the world afford? I'll make my heaven in a lady's lap, And deck my body in gay ornaments, And witch sweet ladies with my words and looks. O miserable thought! and more unlikely Than to accomplish twenty golden crowns! Why, love forswore me in my  mother's womb: And, for I should not deal in her soft laws, She did corrupt frail nature with some bribe, To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub; To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits deformity to mock my body; To shape my legs of an unequal size; To disproportion me in every part, Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp That carries no impression like the dam. And am I then a man to be beloved? O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought! Then, since this earth affords no joy to me, But to command, to cheque, to o'erbear such As are of better person than myself, I'll make my heaven to dream upon the crown, And, whiles I live, to account this world but hell, Until my mis-shaped trunk that bears this head Be round impaled with a glorious crown. And yet I know not how to get the crown, For many lives stand between me and home: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood, That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns, Seeking a way and straying from the way; Not knowing how to find the open air, But toiling desperately to find it out,-- Torment myself to catch the English crown: And from that torment I will free myself, Or hew my way out with a bloody axe. Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile, And cry 'Content' to that which grieves my heart, And wet my cheeks with artificial tears, And frame my face to all occasions. I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall; I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk; I'll play the orator as well as Nestor, Deceive more slily than Ulysses could, And, like a Sinon, take another Troy. I can add colours to the chameleon, Change shapes with Proteus for advantages, And set the murderous Machiavel to school. Can I do this, and cannot get a crown? Tut, were it farther off, I'll pluck it down.
Exit
